For many years, the conventional wisdom was that most acts of aggression and violence stem from insecurities and low self-esteem. 
        Despite this apparent consensus, however, neither a compelling theoretical rationale nor a persuasive body of empirical 
        evidence exists to support the overarching assumption that aggressive and violent people usually suffer from low self-esteem. 
        Nevertheless, this view has been extended to school shooters. Following a series of school shootings in the United States, 
        several organizations (including the U.S. Department of Education) prepared lists of alleged warning signs for identifying 
        possible school shooters, and many of the lists included low self-esteem. The possibility that some mass shooters have low 
        self-esteem, low self-worth, or painful personal insecurities should not lead us to overlook another important possibility: 
        that a significant number of mass shooters may have large egos and narcissistic tendencies.

the overwhelming majority of studies reject that traditional view that low self-esteem is linked to aggression and violence, 
        and instead support the view that narcissism is linked to aggression and violence.

The following pictures and quotes are extracts from videos and writings by Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, the two shooters in the 1999 Columbine highschool shootings. They demonstrate narcissistic personality traits which have also been observed in other school shootings and other acts of extreme violence.

These examples challenge the conventional view of violence and aggression being fueled by low self-esteem. Rather they are one of the many examples pointing at the fact that narcissism - a sense of inflated ego - is connected with antisocial behavior.
